author: ilovegetosuguru
title: a spin around the rumor mill

summary:
Gojo Satoru

Professor in the PHYSICS DEPARTMENT at JUJUTSU TECHNICAL COLLEGE.

PHYS 161
Rating: 1/5

Professor Gojo WILL keep you past scheduled class time to talk about his husband. Make sure you listen because his tests include details about his personal life. I failed the midterm because I didn’t remember their anniversary date.

All in all - DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. The fact that someone actually married this heathen is astounding.

Or, a spin around the rumor mill leads Nobara to the wrong answer.
notes:
A note of thanks to:

Kat, for telling me that I'm not unoriginal, I'm just staying consistent and on brand.

Ally, for always sending me extremely cute twitter posts and screaming about Satosugu.

Sabina, for drawing such sad Satosugu art that I was inspired to finish this fic.

(They're all incredible and you should check out their art^^)

And finally, last but not least, a thanks to Ursa, for helping me through this entire mess.

(See the end of the work for more notes.)

A sequel? PERHAPS! But for now, I'll leave it as a one-shot.

I think I'm funny sometimes. Had a lot of fun writing this.

(Pst...have a fic idea you want me to write? Talk to me on Twitter @saccharinesyrup!)
text:
Gojo Satoru 
Professor in the PHYSICS DEPARTMENT at JUJUTSU TECHNICAL COLLEGE. 

PHYS 161
Rating: 1/5


UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES SHOULD YOU TAKE THIS CLASS. If you are being held at gunpoint and told to take this class, choose death instead. I promise it will be the better option.


Gojo Satoru is, without a doubt, the worst professor at Jujutsu Tech. HE DOES NOT EXPLAIN A SINGLE THING and expects you to already know high-level concepts such as the Schwarzchild metric, Hawking radiation, and gravitational lensing. His presentation slides have so many memes that they’re practically incomprehensible. Good luck taking notes. 


You won’t learn about astrophysics, but Professor Gojo WILL keep you past scheduled class time to talk about his husband. Make sure you listen because his tests include details about his personal life. I failed the midterm because I didn’t remember their anniversary date. 


All in all - DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. The fact that someone actually married this heathen is astounding. 


127 likes • 0 dislikes

 
 
Nobara ends up in PHYS 161 the same way injured animals end up in the zoo: feral, on her last legs, and desperate to escape. Her major (Fashion Merchandising and Design) requires her to take one upper-division science class. PHYS 161 is the last class that has seats available this late in the semester because of one reason and one reason only. 
No one wants to be in a class taught by Professor Gojo Satoru. 
On the outside, Professor Gojo is everything a student could ask for. At age eighteen, he was the youngest person to ever obtain a Nobel Prize in Physics. Now, at age twenty-eight, three Nobel Prizes decorate his bookcases — making him the only three time recipient of the esteemed title. Gojo Satoru’s research in black holes revolutionized the field of astrophysics, allowing his name to be published alongside those such as Albert Einstein and Stephen Hawking. His accolades shine radiantly, flickering like false gold. 
But this is Nobara’s second year at Jujutsu Technical College. She is not so easily fooled. 
Bright-eyed, bushy-tailed first years, eager to learn and drawn by the glamor of Gojo’s accomplishments, quickly discover the truth: 
Professor Gojo’s mastery over physics is heavily outweighed by his abhorrent teaching style. 
Rate My Professor — a website dedicated to helping college students decide which professors to choose and which class to attend— is a place where Professor Gojo’s unique traits are brought to court by a panel of angry students. Currently, he boasts the lowest overall score on the entire website: a meager 1.4 out of 5. According to the criticism of hundreds, it is a score he has very much earned. A reflection of his abysmal grades, lectures, and class structure. 
On the first day of class, he hands out the PHYS 161: Astrophysics syllabus. It contains no information on tests, grading scales, or extra credit, and is instead a modeling portfolio of himself. Half of the class drops. Nobara manages to keep her scream entirely internal. 
On the second day, he gives lecture. Nobara discovers that notes are given in meme format, learns a revolting amount of information about Gojo’s husband, and witnesses every student that is not required to take this class leave midway through.
Lucky bastards, she thinks, scowling as she tries to draw the mathematical formula shaped as the grumpy cat meme accurately in her notebook.
On the third day, they are given a pop quiz, which consists of questions such as: 

“How did Professor Gojo meet his absolute wonderful and stunning husband?” 

“What did Professor Gojo cook on his fifth anniversary? List the ingredients and recipe in correct order.” 
And, “Make a dimensional analysis of the equation of hydrostatic equilibrium using a polytropic equation of state to find a general mass-radius relation for spherically symmetric, self-gravitating bodies. For which two polytropic indices is the configuration unstable?”
Nobara watches as three people formally draft their intention for withdrawal and drop out of Jujutsu Technical College by the time the testing period ends. 
On the fourth day, when the quiz is returned, Nobara considers homicide. The 33%, written in sparkling pink gel pen and covered in poorly drawn flowers, gives rise to an anger so powerful that she snaps her pencil in half. Her vision, briefly, goes red. 
But murdering Gojo is not an option. She cannot achieve her dreams of becoming an influencer from prison. They don’t allow phones. 
Nobara must survive. 
Even worse, Nobara must pass. 
And there’s only one way to do so. 
Every year, there’s a very specific question included on the final. Answering correctly guarantees an A+ in the class. 

Who is Professor Gojo’s husband?

No student, in Gojo’s Satoru’s ten years of teaching, has managed to figure out the answer. 
Nobara’s determined to be the first. 
 
 
PHYS 161
Rating: 2/5

Asks for questions and then insults you for 30 minutes. I went to office hours for help and he laughed in my face. 


However, I try to be optimistic about all my classes and so it must be said: Professor Gojo is incredibly good looking, and it makes class somewhat worth taking. One time, he joked that my boyfriend was cheating on me and we broke up the next day :/

68 likes • 0 dislikes 
 
 
“Professor Gojo’s husband?” Junpei asks, wiping down the espresso machine. “Sorry, I have no idea who it is.” 
Nobara crushes the empty coffee cup in her hands as if she’s imagining it’s Gojo’s head, anger so palpable that Junpei can almost feel it bubbling off her skin. 
Earlier today, she had stormed into her shift with a twenty percent on the midterm, a grade that was decidedly not passing, but apparently higher than average. Junpei has never taken a class by Professor Gojo, and after almost a semester of hearing Nobara’s horror stories, he’s sure he never will. 
“No one else does either,” she says venomously. “How could anyone marry that man?” 
Junpei mulls over the question for a second, but there’s really only one answer. “I guess they must really love each other,” he says, but he grimaces as soon as the words leave his mouth. 
The thought of Professor Gojo doing anything that can be classified as romance is horrifying in its own way. 
Nobara mirrors his expression, disgust written all over her face. She quickly steers the conversation back to their previous topic. “I know it has to be another professor,” she says, moving from the tables to the pastry display. “Because he’s said that they both teach here.” 
“That makes sense,” Junpei agrees, filtering through his memories for his brief encounters with Gojo. “He orders two large drinks every morning. I doubt he could drink all of it by himself.” 
“What does he order?” 
“A strawberry frappuccino with five pumps of syrup, two shots of vanilla,” Junpei recites, remembering the first time he had accidentally made it with four pumps of syrup instead of five. Gojo had complained that it wasn’t sweet, even though the drink was already sugary enough to give the average person a heart attack three times over. “Extra caramel, extra strawberry, chocolate chips—“
“How the hell is he still alive—“
“— And extra whip cream,” Junpei finishes. “And also a plain black coffee. I assume that’s for his husband.” 
“The strawberry frappuccino sounds sickening,” she says. “And if Gojo’s drink has anything to say about his appearance, then I bet his husband is just like black coffee: tall, dark, and handsome.” 
Junpei tries to think of a professor that fits the description. There is one that comes to mind, but the thought is so absurd that he almost brushes it away. It’s only after his second sweep of general college trivia that it swings back around. “Professor Getou sort of fits…” 
“Professor Getou? The philosophy professor?” Nobara raises an eyebrow curiously, wordlessly handing him a bag of coffee beans. “I thought they hated each other.” 
“I’m pretty sure they do,” he agrees, putting the coffee beans into the coffee grinder. “When we were learning the trolley problem, Professor Getou photoshopped Professor Gojo’s face onto the people being run over. I just can’t think of anyone else.” 
“Maybe they want us to think that they hate each other,” Nobara exclaims. “It’s the perfect diversion tactic!” 
It seems really far fetched, but he honestly doesn’t have any better ideas, so he might as well go along with it. “I guess.” 
“I need to be sure before I answer the question,” Nobara says, seemingly lost in thought. She turns to him, eyes flashing dangerously and voice covered in syrup. “You’ll help me find out, won’t you?”
He hesitates. 
On one hand, Junpei is failing biology. The only romance he should be concerned about is the mating rituals of the bowerbird. 
On the other hand, he knows that Nobara takes Taekwondo in her free time and has a hobby of collecting blackmail material on their mutual friends. He doesn’t want to be on her bad side. 
Glancing again at the destroyed coffee cup, torn to pieces and resembling the chew toy of a particularly rabid dog, Junpei makes his decision. “I’ll try.” 
 
 

PHYS 161
Rating: 2/5


Why would anyone marry Professor Gojo, you ask? 


Allow me present to you the following theory:


Professor Gojo’s husband is in witness protection. He’s on the run, he’s in debt, and there’s dangerous people that want his head on a platter. 


The solution? 


Adopt a new identity, marry Professor Gojo so that he can change his last name, and integrate himself back into normal civilian life to escape from Tokyo’s dark underbelly.


I know it’s insane. But honestly, I can’t think of any other scenario in which someone would want to spend the rest of their lives with Professor Gojo. 

46 likes • 0 dislikes 
 
 
Fushigoro can feel Junpei staring at him from across the library table, peering to the side of the stack of textbooks he’s put in front of him. He knows the next sentence Junpei says is going to be off topic before he even opens his mouth. 
“You’ve known Professor Gojo for a long time,” Junpei begins. 
“Don’t remind me,” he groans, trying to finish copying his anatomy notes. 
“Sorry,” Junpei says. He does look slightly apologetic, the same way people do when asking someone else to recall an unpleasant experience such as eating a lemon, but also doesn’t look apologetic enough to let the topic change despite Fushigoro’s discomfort. “He’s married to Professor Getou right?” 
“Is he?” Fushigoro frowns. That means that he will have to remove Getou from his list of respectable professors and won’t be able to take any of his classes. Which is a shame because he was looking forward to taking philosophy next year. 
Gojo is married to Getou. He writes the information down in the top corner of his notebook as a reminder to change his schedule. 
Junpei shrugs, opening up a borrowed textbook. “I don’t know, but Nobara thinks they are. I’m trying to help her figure it out.” 
So it was just guessing then. He tries to erase the reminder and notices that he’d written it in non-erasable pen, so he settles for crossing a line through it. 
“Did she blackmail you?” Fushigoro has been on the losing end of that deal many times. Telling her about his crush on Itadori was one of his biggest mistakes. 
“I think the only reason she hasn’t is because I don’t have social media,” Junpei says. “She hasn’t found anything yet.” 
“I’m surprised she hasn’t found the answer from Gojo’s social media,” Fushigoro says, just as a text message from Nanako pops up on his phone. It’s a screenshot of Gojo’s latest tweet: a picture of him modeling the latest Versace Renewed Love line, captioned ‘felt cute, might delete later’. 
Nanako’s text just below reads: In case you forgot, you owe me a shopping trip. 
His default response to Gojo’s tweets is a mild irritation, equivalent to a singular ant crawling on his skin. Nanako only sends him screenshots when she wants to annoy him, so Fushigoro types out an agreement before he’s hit with more spam. 
“Anyways,” Junpei says, “Would you mind explaining the mating rituals of bowerbirds again?” 
He nods, perusing the stack of textbooks until he finds the right one. “Bowerbirds,” Fushigoro explains, flipping to a photograph of a bird hoarding shiny pebbles, “like to decorate their nest with sticks and brightly colored objects to attract a mate.” 
“I bet that’s how Gojo got his husband.” 
“By collecting shiny rocks?”
“No,” Junpei laughs. “By bribing him.” 
“I don’t think so,” Fushigoro says wryly. “There’s not enough money in the world for that.” 
 
 

PHYS 161
Rating: 1/5


I literally saw him steal candy from a baby???????

92 likes • 0 dislikes 
 
 
“I can’t tell the difference,” Fushigoro says. 
It’s clear that he’s colorblind, because Nanako can’t even begin to fathom how the two pieces of clothing look anything alike. 
“This one,” Nanako points to the sweater on the right, “is lilac.”
“And this one,” she gestures to the sweater on the left. “is lavender!” 
He looks at them both with an empty stare before saying, with a voice as flat as the Sahara desert, “They’re the same color.” 
She takes them both back and sighs, hanging the lavender one back on the wall. “It’s my mistake. I shouldn’t ask you for fashion advice when you have hair like that.” 
He reaches up to touch his hair, confusion flashing across his face. “What’s wrong with my hair?” 
“What isn’t wrong with your hair?” Nanako counters. Frankly, it looked like someone had accidentally run over a porcupine and then attempted to reshape it back to its original form. “Did you know that you’re blacklisted from the hair salons around here? I tried setting up an appointment but they all said no when they saw a picture of you.” 
“You could’ve at least asked me first.” 
“I asked Tsumiki and she said you needed one.” Nanako brushes off the comment, browsing the assortment of shirts with a practiced eye. “Besides, you would’ve said no.” 
Fushigoro doesn’t respond, which is practically an admittance of guilt by itself. 
“Did you see the new Versace line that Gojo was wearing?” She asks, bringing up Gojo because she knows it irks Fushigoro. “I heard that they literally sent it to him because his family owns a large portion of shares in the company.”
Nanako doesn’t really expect Fushigoro to answer, so she’s pleasantly surprised when he does, even though the actual sentence matter steers the conversation in an entirely different direction. 
“Nobara thinks he’s married to Professor Getou,” he says. 
“Absolutely not,” she responds. The idea in and of itself is so ridiculous that it’s not even worth pursuing. 
“How would you know?” 
“It’s just common sense.” She flicks a hand causally as she hands him another outfit. “Everyone knows that Getou hates Gojo.” 
He still looks doubtful, so she continues. As one of Getou’s most dedicated students, she’s attended every one of his classes and has born witness to the rivalry between the two professors first hand. 
“Getou set up a mock debate with Gojo over utilitarianism once and I swear they were seconds away from strangling each other,” she says. “Gojo annoys him too much.” 
Fushigoro processes the information, a wearisome look crossing his face before suggesting, “Maybe it’s a loveless marriage.” 
Nanako pauses, considering. 
In a weird, twisted sort of way, it made sense. There was always a strange tension in their arguments that she’d never been able to explain, something that bordered on romance and violence simultaneously. 
“You might be right,” she says slowly. “Who knew you were so smart?” 
He rolls his eyes from behind the pile of clothing. “I have better grades than you.” 
“Yeah,” Nanako agrees, flicking at a stray strand of Fushigoro’s hair and takes in the miniature disaster happening on his head. She holds up the sweater, “But sea urchins don’t have eyes or brains, so sometimes, I wonder.” 
“Whatever,” he grumbles, reaching for his bag as he’s reminded of schoolwork. “Could you pass these notes too Itadori for me?” 
“Sure.” She smiles wolfishly as she’s handed the copy. “If you do a Tiktok dance with me.”
“Absolutely not.” Fushigoro attempts to take the notes back, but Nanako anticipates the move and sidesteps out of the way quickly. “I spent two hours on those!”
“And it’ll take five seconds for me to rip them apart,” she sings threateningly, holding them as if she were going to tear the papers to shreds. Fushigoro’s appearance is sure to boost her and Mimiko’s verified account, which currently sits at 999.7K followers. The internet loves dark haired brooding types. 
Besides, she knows that Fushigoro doesn’t have time to re-do his notes. He has a quiz in Marine Biology with professor Amanai tomorrow.
Conflict wars on Fushigoro’s face, twisting as he weighs the pros and cons. Nanako wiggles the notebook over a nearby trashcan while she waits for his decision. 
“Fine,” he concedes at last, glaring as if she had just single-handedly caused his life’s biggest regret. 
Nanako grins. She’ll have to start planning for their one million follower celebration. 
 
 

PHYS 161
Rating: 1/5


I am 90% sure Professor Gojo has a humiliation kink or something. He’s been kicked out of Professor Getou’s class so many times and just keeps coming back. 

10 likes • 0 dislikes 
 
 
There’s a box of earrings on Professor Getou’s desk. A string of black crystals connected by a glimmering silver thread, shaped to look like a multitude of miniature dragonflies. 
Mimiko arrives fifteen minutes early to office hours, finds that Getou has not yet appeared, and is the first to notice the jewelry. She peers over the earrings curiously, attempting to find a price tag and a brand name. It wasn’t quite her style, but she couldn’t deny that whoever chose them had great taste. 
She takes out her phone, scrolling past Gojo’s latest tweet: STOP SAYING I WEAR CONTACTS THEY’RE REAL! I have very blue eyes! They just change color based on the weather :), and opening the location app to find where Nanako is. The blue dot blinks at her, right outside the office hallway. 
Nanako opens the doorway roughly, hinges swinging open to hit the back wall with her phone in her hands, dropping her bag into her seat gracelessly. She scrolls furiously on the screen. “You’ll never guess what I found out.” 
Mimiko perks up and immediately goes over, earrings forgotten. It’s been a long time since there’s been any notable gossip around here. Fushigoro having a crush on Itadori was old news at this point, considering that neither of them had done anything. “What is it?” 
“Professor Gojo and Getou used to be married,” Nanako says, as if she doesn’t quiet believe it but has some irrefutable proof that it’s the truth. 
Mimiko is in the same boat. Though the two professors had always had a fuzzy relationship — the majority of the school believed that they were mortal enemies, but a select few thought otherwise — surely Getou had better options. They weren’t even in the same league. 
To clarify, she presses for more information. “What do you mean ‘used to be’?” 
“They probably divorced ten years ago,” Nanako explains, pulling up records of Gojo’s old tweets. “Look, he didn’t tweet for an entire week. It probably happened then.” 
She looks at the screen, the time stamp indicating the ten year difference. In 2007, there is an entire week without new posts. 
Gojo tweeted often throughout the course of a day, usually during times when he was suppose to be giving lecture. For him to be silent on social media for an entire week — something drastic must have happened during that time. 
It’s not solid proof of anything, but it’s just enough for Nanako’s theory to be plausible.
“But Gojo’s married,” Mimiko points out the flaw. “He talks about his husband all the time during lecture and wears a silver ring on his left hand.” 
“That’s the problem. I think Gojo’s been faking it. They broke up years ago and Gojo pretends they’re still together because he’s not over it yet.” 
Pretending to still be married in order to save face is an act that is incredibly petty. Unfortunately, it also seems like something Gojo would do. Mimiko’s time in astrophysics had been half-spent listening to Gojo’s life story, each and every one more outlandish than the last, tales including feats such as: saving an orphan, fighting a shark with his bare hands, and being a target for government assassins. There was no way all of them were true, so it wasn’t that much of a stretch to think he would lie about his husband. 
To add on to the theory, Mimiko proposes an additional detail, “I think Getou got remarried.” 
“Oh?” Nanako’s eyes grow wider. 
“Look at the earrings on his desk,” she says, pointing at the jewelry. “It’s too intimate to be a thank you gift from a colleague or student, and it’s far too expensive to be an ordinary gift for a friend.” 
“Those look familiar…” Nanako says. She squints at them before pulling up something on her phone. “I have a picture somewhere…got it!” 
She shows her a picture of Gojo’s latest modeling campaign. “They’re from the latest Versace Renewed Love collection. So they’re probably—” 
“—an anniversary present,” Mimiko finishes.
They grin at each other, both glad that Getou finally has someone that is worthy of his time. 
As if on cue, Professor Getou opens the door. He glances at them and, noting the upward slant on their faces that are frequently associated with mischief, asks, “Do I want to know?” 
“Nope!” Nanako chirps. “Just glad that the marriage is going well, Professor.” 
A flicker of surprise crosses his face. Then, it eases into a relaxed smile. “Thank you Nanako,” he says, crossing the room and putting his papers to the side, picking up the box of earrings with a small laugh. “Was this what gave it away?” 
Mimiko and Nanako nod in unison. 
“Well, it was bound to come out eventually. I’m surprised this whole facade lasted this long to be honest.” Getou stashes the box away and extracts a folder filled with what Mimiko recognizes as their end-of-the-quarter essays. “Give me a second to organize and we can discuss your grades after.” 
As Getou sorts his documents, Nanako fishes out a notebook from her bag. “Can you give this to Itadori? It’s from Megumi.” 
“Sure,” Mimiko says, transferring it to her backpack. She hopes Fushigoro knows that she will be doodling hearts around every word. 
 
 

PHYS 161
Rating: 3/5


I’m not in Professor Gojo’s class, but he burst into Anatomy 101 with Professor Shoko during our women’s reproduction unit. He was holding a fake baby and accidentally fell. The baby’s head rolled off. He then proceeded to dramatically fake-cry for thirty minutes straight. 


On the plus side, our pop quiz was canceled. 

87 likes • 5 dislikes 
 
 
“Here.” Mimiko drops the notebook into Itadori’s lap. “From Megumi.” 
Itadori clutches the notebook like a man given water after a day under scorching sun. He’s currently on the verge of failing Professor Shoko’s anatomy class. If he fails, he knows the following events would occur:
Due to his grades, he’d lose the ability to play for their university’s baseball team, the school would no longer fund his sports scholarship, Sukuna would be notified, and Itadori would end up on a true crime podcast for his mysterious death. He is 99% certain that Sukuna would not be caught. 
Itadori opens the notebook as he attempts to memorize the words like the gospel, and stops when he sees a scribbled out note in the top left corner. He reads aloud, “Gojo is married to Getou?” 
“No, that’s false,” Mimiko corrects, waving a hand as if to dissipate his confusion. “Gojo isn’t actually married, he’s just pretending he is so he can save face.” 
Itadori has never had either of these professors and feels like he is missing some vital context. “Um…okay?” 
“Getou is married though,” she continues, clarifying something that does not need to be clarified. “He got an early anniversary gift today.” 
“Good for him?” He asks uncertainly, still unsure of how to proceed with this conversation. 
“It is good for him, isn’t it?” She asks, seemingly very happy about this turn of events. “Getou deserves better.” 
“Definitely,” Itadori says, knowing that arguing with Mimiko on any topic regarding Professor Getou was a losing battle. 
Mimiko looks satisfied with his agreement. Then she says, “Are you ready for the test today?”
Itadori feels a shiver run down his spine at the word test, the ghost of death’s scythe across his neck as Professor Shoko walks into the room. She’s holding something that looks suspiciously like multiple choice bubble sheets. His voice shakes ever so slightly when he asks, “What test?”
The look of pity Mimiko gives him is answer enough. 
Itadori wonders if he has time to write his will before Sukuna finds him. 
 
 

PHYS 161
Rating: 1/5


I tried to sue this professor for emotional distress but it turns out he has tenure. Good luck.

7 likes • 0 dislikes 
 
 
Tradition for university students dictates pulling all nighters the week before finals. Itadori has had two 24-hour energy drinks in the span of an hour and can feel his brain beginning to sputter like an abandoned car running on low gas. While Fushigoro’s notes were normally spotless, these ones were the exception. A colorful array of hearts decorated every sentence. It was hard to read. 
His current situation limits his choices down to two potential courses of action. Option 1: He will fail and Sukuna will kill him. Option 2: He will pass and the amount of caffeine he has consumed will stop his heart. 
Itadori decides that the second option will have less suffering. He reaches for his third energy drink. 
Across from him, Nobara is holding profiles for every member of the faculty. Itadori has no idea how this constitutes as studying. 
“It’s Professor Getou,” Nobara declares, staring down at the papers. “No one else makes sense.” 
As always, procrastination wins out against good study habits. He welcomes the distraction, “What makes sense?” 
“Professor Gojo’s husband. There’s no one else it could possibly be.” 
“I thought Professor Gojo didn’t have a husband?” Itadori asks, confused. “Mimiko said he was faking it.” 
Nobara’s head snaps up, eyes sharpening. “Are you sure?”
“…yes?” 
A moment of silence falls as the realization washes over Nobara. Itadori, recognizing the quiet before the storm, slowly moves his things out of the way. He thinks he can almost hear the sound of her temper cracking.
“I  hate  Gojo,” Nobara bursts, slamming her case files down. Beside them, a random student jumps, startled from the sudden movement. “Of course he’d do something like this. Of course it’s a trick question.”
“At least you know the answer now,” Itadori offers, quickly abandoning all hope of passing Shoko’s class. He still has a hundred pages left to read from their textbook. “Sukuna’s going to kill me after I fail.”
“I’d rather face Sukuna than be in Gojo’s class,” Nobara scowls. “Sukuna kills you, but Gojo makes you suffer.” 
“Fair,” Itadori says, doubling down on his earlier choice and reaching for a fourth energy drink. 
 
 

PHYS 161
Rating: 2/5


There is something deeply, deeply wrong with this man. 


31 likes • 0 dislikes

 
 
On the final exam, there is a question. 
Who is Professor Gojo’s husband? 
With the confidence of Alexander conquering the world, Nobara writes her answer. 
 
 

PHYS 161
Rating: 5/5


Incredible. 10/10 would recommend this professor.

0 likes • 376 dislikes 
 
 
Sunlight spills across the sage green walls of the living room, pouring like honey and dispelling light upon Getou’s book, held delicately in one hand as his other holds a cup of warm tea. The picture of comfort and relaxation, which promptly shatters as the door slams open. 
“I’m single!” Gojo wails, throwing his folders onto the coffee table and flopping onto the couch like a boneless worm. 
Getou does not look up from his book. “Are you? Congratulations.” 
“My students said I'm making it up!” Gojo whines, inching forward and pushing the book out of the way to rest his head on Getou’s lap. “They don't think that I'm actually married!” 
Getou reaches across to put his tea down on the table, careful not to spill. He then uses the free hand to brush across Gojo’s hair gently. Gojo melts into the touch like a stray cat, and Getou resists the urge to take a picture. “It is hard to believe that someone would marry you.”
“Rude!” Gojo exclaims, rolling over to give him the stink eye. “I want a divorce.” 
“I’ve heard that we’ve already had a divorce,” Getou says, smiling fondly down at him. “Apparently, I am now married to someone else and you are my clingy ex-husband.” 
Gojo scoffs. “As though anyone else could live up to my standards. Why aren’t we married in any of the rumors?” 
He shrugs. “If you didn’t want gossip to spread, you could just tell the truth.” 
“But I want to have fun,” Gojo protests, pouting. 
Getou thinks for a moment, setting the book on the couch as he hums. “We could start a rumor of our own,” he proposes. “That we are married, but we’re thinking of getting a divorce.” 
The reveal of their relationship would be shocking enough to spread like wildfire and the intrigue of their potential divorce would be scandalous enough to stay under the spotlight. 
Gojo stares up at Getou like he’s rediscovering a universe before saying, “I love you.” 
“Thank you,” Getou says cooly, refusing to flush underneath his gaze. 
When Getou doesn’t say anything else, he frowns. “You aren’t going to say it back?” 
“I’m afraid not. We’re getting a divorce, remember?”
“Tomorrow!” Gojo declares, pulling him down by the collar so that their faces are inches away. “Not today!” 
“Tomorrow then,” Getou says, laughing as Gojo begins kissing his face. “I love you too.”
